Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multireference Studies of Organic Polyradicals, Radical Reactions and Graphene Nanoribbons
Award.AbstractNarration:
Carol Parish at the University of Richmond and Hans Lischka at Texas Tech University are supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational methods program to perform theoretical investigations of the structures, reactivities and excited states of di-, tetra- and poly-radical molecules important to understanding reaction mechanisms, pyrolysis and combustion of alternative fuels, anticancer antibiotics and graphene nanodevices. A fundamental understanding of the proper physical characterization of polyradicals is critically important for the further development of multireference (MR) electronic structure theory as well as understanding and controlling chemical phenomenon involving these open-shell intermediates. This proposal focuses on utilizing MR methods (MR-CI, MR-AQCC, CASPT2) to study 1.) model systems such as the geometries and excites states of o-, m- and p-benzyne, 2.) diradical intermediates found in the pyrolyis of asphaltene heteroaromatic compounds, 3.) novel electrocyclization reactions producing diradical intermediates that may function as anticancer antibiotics, 4.) reactions involving tetraradicals and the role that through-bond coupling plays in radical electron interaction, 5.) diradical and multiradical defects in graphene and to benchmark these MR methods against DFT results and 6.) developing input and analysis tools for the COLUMBUS package to facilitate the use of these highly correlated MR methods by the chemical community including undergraduate students.

The ability to characterize properly open-shell polyradical species and the corresponding investigation of novel cyclization reactions holds significant promise for advancing the fields of MR theoretical chemistry, mechanistic organic chemistry, materials design and drug optimization. The proposal delineates several carefully conceived theoretical experiments designed to be performed by undergraduate researchers, graduate students and post-baccalaureate or post-doctoral fellows. This will create a community of scientists focusing on the proper characterization of interesting polyradical species using state-of-the-art electronic structure methods. Students at all levels will learn the details of computational quantum mechanics, spectroscopy and methods development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Diradicals and polyradicals play an increasingly important role in unconventional chemical reactions and for the design of advanced materials. Highly topical and fascinating research fields range from engineering graphene nanoflakes to organic superconductors, molecular magnets and bio-organic reactions with great success potential in applied material sciences. Among these topics graphene is one of the most promising current materials composed of a single atomic layer of fused benzene rings. Because of its remarkable physical, thermal and electrical properties it provides the basis for interesting applications in electronics, optoelectronics and photonics which will lead to a new era of technical devices changing industrial applications and materials used in our everyday life. One of the most challenging tasks to achieve these goals is the ability to introduce defects into the per se regular network of carbon atoms in a controlled manner. “Band-gap engineering” is the specific technical term. To achieve this objective a huge amount of experiments and costly lab tests have to be performed. To facilitate these huge tasks, computer simulations constitute extremely useful tools which can aid in the pre-selection of materials and can shorten technical development cycles substantially.

In the theoretical investigations performed with the support of the present grant the remarkable electronic properties of special defect structures in graphene nanosheets are being explored. This work combines quantum chemical software development activities based on the public domain program system COLUMBUS and the detailed examination of the chemical reactivity of a particularly interesting kind of defects in the form of carbon vacancies as shown in red in Image 1.

A reactive hydrogen atom Hr has been used as a test particle to explore the affinity of the defect (Image 2, left) in forming chemical bonds by moving it in a plane parallel to the pyrene molecule as indicated by the arrows. The results are astonishing: the dark violet regions depicted in the contour diagrams (Image 2, right) of the energy scan indicate the extended range of chemical activity across the graphene defect region forming the nucleus for creating islands of chemisorbed areas once a single defect has been created externally. This research will e.g. help in constructing certain “roads” on the graphene sheet along which electron transport will be preferential and the above-mentioned band gaps cannot be controlled appropriately.

Another class of organic compounds, the zethrenes (Image 3), possess a seemingly stable electronic configuration which can, however, be modified in a way that chemically reactive biradicals are formed which can be used as the basic material for creating new optoelectronic devices. Also in this case, high-level quantum chemical modeling is used to support the development processes of new materials. 

Image 3 shows the unpaired density, a quantity measuring the free valence in a molecule, which indicates in detail where the chemical reactivity in this molecule is located. This information is very useful in determining sensitive areas in the molecule and indicate where chemical modifications should be made. This information will be helpful in deciding on specific variations of these molecules and will contribute in reducing tedious laboratory work in synthesizing a large number of target molecules.
